column1: #Text=Our most gracious sovereigns birth-day was celebrated in this town, on Monday, with the usual demonstrations of loyalty and attachment to the throne.
#Text=The day was ushered in by the firing of cannon and the ringing of bells, and from various commanding eminences, flags, with appropriate inscriptions, were exhibited.
#Text=Precisely at half-past ten the detachment of artillery, consisting of two guns, under the command of Major Emmett, and the 15th Hussars, commanded by Lieut.
#Text=Anns-square from their barracks at Hulme, and formed in two lines fronting each other, the Artillery occupying that portion of the square next to Exchange-street.
#Text=Shortly afterwards the 91st Regiment of Foot, commanded by Lieut.

#Text=Anderson, at present stationed at the Regent-road barracks, marched into town, and took the station prescribed for them, lining the foot£aths on each side of Market-street, and extending from >ucie-place almost to High-street.

#Text=At eleven oclock the civil authorities, consisting of the boroughreeve and constables, the magistrates of the division, the churchwardens, &c, took up their station between the two files of Hussars in St.

#Text=Anns-square, and after a mutual salute, the procession moved off in the order stated in the programme which we published last week, along Marketstreet, Piccadilly, and London-roa;l, to Ard wick-green, and after passing round the southern extremity of the green, the cavalry and infantry formed in line on the eastern side.
#Text=The Artillery, which took its station at the north end, then fired a royal salute of twenty-one guns, every seventh discharge being followed by a feu de joie by the cavalry and infantry.
#Text=The ceremony terminated with three hearty cheers, the bands playing "God save the king."

#Text=The procession then returned to town in the same order, but varying the route, down Mosley-*treet, York-street, and King-street, and on arriving at the Town Hall, the civil authorities formed in the piazza of that building, and after swluting the military, the procession separated.

#Text=The day was rather cloudy, and a very slight shower fell during the time occupied by the ceremony ; but notwithstanding this, the concourse of spectators alog<y the line of the procession, as well as on the green, was hi/mense.
#Text=We have not heard of the occurrence of a single accident.
